title-group.article-title: Late-Holocene successional dynamics in a transitional forest of west-central Mexico

article-meta.aff: 1Centro Universitario de la Costa Sur, Universidad de Guadalajara, Mexico

author-notes.corresp: Blanca L. Figueroa-Rangel, Departamento de Ecología y Recursos Naturales-IMECBIO, Centro Universitario de la Costa Sur, Universidad de Guadalajara, Apartado Postal 108, Autlán de Navarro, Jalisco, C.P. 49800, México. Email: bfrangel@cucsur.udg.mx

abstract.p: The determination of past successional stages, as well as the factors triggering succession, is crucial for the understanding of forest dynamics and the design of current and future management and conservation strategies. Shifts between successional stages can take decades or even centuries to occur because of tree longevity; therefore palaeoecological studies are important tools for their study. The present research involved the palaeoreconstruction of a transitional forest dominated by Pinus-Carpinus-Quercus in west-central Mexico over the last ~1230 years. The proxies employed include fossil pollen, microscopic fossil charcoal, magnetic susceptibility and organic matter content evaluated by multivariate techniques. The findings reveal that an initial cloud forest stage developed from 1230 to 1050 cal. yr BP. This stage was then interrupted for ~400 years (1050–690 cal. yr BP) when a regional climate change event decreased the number of cloud forest taxa and increased herbaceous taxa including Asteraceae, Poaceae, Plantago and Zea. The cloud forest stage recovered at 690 cal. yr BP and the community has persisted to the present time, yet this stage is dominated by human-induced taxa such as Pinus and Acacia. Whilst the dynamics of individual taxa were related to forest fires and soil erosion, changes between community types were related to an interval of regional climate change (greater aridity) that occurred between 1050 and 690 cal. yr BP. Results from this study indicate that, in order to preserve the cloud forest stage, human disturbances such as logging and agriculture should be excluded; a conservation strategy established in the transitional forest in recent years.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Historical factors play a primary role in vegetation change and evidence of former responses to environmental perturbations can provide important baselines for prediction of future change (Jackson, 2007; Motzkin et al., 2003; Myster and Pickett, 1990; Swetnam et al., 1999). Analyzing the past community composition in a forest, its abundance, the way it was assembled, as well as the environmental variability over time, generates substantial information for our understanding of current forest characteristics.

Succession is the modification of the plant assemblage into a different state over time following disturbance (Davis et al., 2005). Several models of forest succession have been described including the cyclic model first developed by Watt (1947). This model suggests that following a perturbation the initial stage turns into one or more intermediate stages before returning to the original one (Frelich, 2002). The conversion to intermediate stages can be triggered by internal and/or external factors such as disturbance and competition (Rogers and Hartnett, 2001). The creation of new spaces for colonization following disturbances changes taxa dominance over time (Fargione and Tilman, 2005; Mamolos, 2006). If fire is the disturbance factor that triggers succession, competition between thermophilous and non-thermophilous species tends to occur (Bataineh et al., 2006; Carrion and van Geel, 1999; Carrion et al., 2003). In other cases where climatic factors such as precipitation and temperature are involved, turnover between wet and dry-resistant species has been demonstrated (Guarin and Taylor, 2005; Parmesan and Yohe, 2003).

Palaeoclimatic and palaeoecological records have documented the influence of climate change on various plant communities over centennial time scales in Central, South and North Mexico (Almeida-Lenero et al., 2005; Arnauld et al., 1997; Hodell et al., 2005; Metcalfe et al., 2000). In these regions there is also evidence of human-induced vegetation change, including the transformation of land into fallows or open grassland through clearing and burning (Almeida-Lenero et al., 2005; Beach et al., 2006; Conserva and Byrne, 2002; Lozano-Garcia and Vazquez-Selem, 2005; Ludlow-Wiechers et al., 2005; McClung de Tapia, 2000; Pope et al., 2001; Sluyter and Dominguez, 2006; Xelhuantzi-Lopez, 1994).

In west-central Mexico, the palaeoecological record has documented pine (Figueroa-Rangel et al., 2008) and cloud forest dynamics (Figueroa-Rangel et al., 2010) over the last millennia. In both forests, vegetation change has been influenced by intervals of aridity (~1200–850 cal. yr BP), burning and human disturbances.

A third forest type to occur in this region is a so-called transitional forest which is dominated by Pinus, Carpinus and Quercus. This forest type is a mixture of cloud forest components (Carpinus, Clethra, Cornus, Tilia and Buddleja) with a high abundance (number of individuals per area) and dominance (given basal area and canopy position) of Pinus, but also a high frequency of Quercus. The transitional forest can be classified as a cloud forest, a pine forest or as a pine-oak forest; however, the exact demarcation is difficult because of the intermingled nature of the forest. To assess the status of this forest, it is essential to distinguish the stages in succession that lead to its current state. Here we present evidence for the development of successional stages in this forest over several centuries (last ~1230 yr) using palaeoecological methods and a variety of proxies including fossil pollen, microscopic fossil charcoal, magnetic susceptibility and organic matter content. Key questions addressed in this study include: Did the transitional forest develop via distinct successional stages during the last ~1230 yr or has it remained constant over time? How long did each successional stage last? What were the main drivers for forest succession, human-induced or climate-induced disturbances?

sec.title: Study area
sec.p: The study site is a transitional forest (dominated by Pinus, Carpinus and Quercus) in the Sierra de Manantlan Biosphere Reserve (SMBR). The SMBR is located in the Sierra Madre del Sur physiographic province in west-central Mexico between 19°35′34″N and 104°16′46″W at 1880–2100 m a.s.l. (Figure 1). The geology predominantly comprises igneous rocks from the Cretaceous and early Tertiary (Quintero-Aguilar and Martinez-Rivera, 1993). The climate, according to Köppen and modified by García (1987), is temperate subhumid with mean yearly temperatures between 5°C and 18°C and average rainfall of 1500 mm.

caption.p: Map of the study area with the location of the transitional forest in west-central Mexico

sec.p: In the transitional forest, Pinus douglasiana dominates the canopy followed by Quercus species (Q. candicans, Q. praineana and Q. scytophylla). Other species associated with the main canopy dominants include Alnus jorullensis, Clethra vicentina, Cornus disciflora, Prunus cortapico, Tilia americana var. mexicana and Buddleja sp. Dominant herbs include Castilleja arvensis, Euphorbia schlechtendalii, Festuca breviglumis, Melinis minutiflora, Muhlenbergia dumosa, Senecio salignus, Stevia sp. and Solanum sp. (Vazquez-Garcia et al., 1995). The transitional forest is located in the core zone of the SMBR, a protected area where no human interference (grazing, timber harvesting, or agriculture) is allowed.

sec.title: Field and laboratory techniques
sec.p: A 152 cm sediment core of black organic material was recovered from a forest hollow (27 m × 11 m in diameter) located in the transitional forest of the SMBR using a modified Livingstone corer (Moore et al., 1991). A forest hollow is a small wet depression within forests; it can preserve sediment with fossil pollen that represent records of stand-scale vegetation change (Calcote, 1995, 1998).

Two cores were collected from adjacent coring positions ensuring that any gap in the first sequence was covered in the overlapping samples. The core was described in the field and wrapped in cling-film and aluminium foil. Samples were analysed throughout the sequence for pollen, microscopic fossil charcoal, magnetic susceptibility and organic matter content. Subsamples of 1 cm3 were used for pollen extraction through the standard acetolysis method described by Bennett and Willis (2001). A known quantity of the exotic spore Lycopodium was added to each sample in order to estimate pollen (pollen grains/cm3) and microscopic fossil charcoal concentrations (charcoal cm2/cm3) (Stockmarr, 1971). Pollen and spores were identified using comprehensive pollen and spore reference collection prepared with regional material specific to the study area and the reference collection of the Oxford Long-term Ecology Laboratory.

Microscopic fossil charcoal abundance was quantified in each level analyzed for pollen using the point count method (Clark, 1982). This was treated as a proxy for fire incidence within the pollen source area (Figueiral and Mosbrugger, 2000; Moore, 2000). Magnetic susceptibility (Nowaczyk, 2004) and organic matter content were used as a proxy for soil erosion.

sec.title: Data analysis
sec.p: The chronology for the sequence was established from accelerator mass spectrometry (AMS) 14C dates (Poznań Radiocarbon Laboratory, Poland) and supplemented with 210Pb dates (Ortec Coaxial Well Photon Detector in the Oxford Long-term Ecology Laboratory) of organic material taken from the sedimentary sequence.
The AMS radiocarbon dates were calibrated using the CALIB v5.02 computer program (Stuiver and Reimer, 1993) and the data set INTCAL04.14 (Reimer et al., 2004).

For 210Pb dating the top of the core was analyzed by applying the constant rate of supply (CRS) model (Appleby and Oldfield, 1978). The age–depth model was developed using linear interpolation including 14C and 210Pb dates (Bennett, 1994). Pollen percentages were plotted and analysed using PSIMPOLL 4.25 and PSCOMB 1.03 software (Bennett, 2005). Zonation was undertaken by optimal splitting and significant zones were resolved using a broken-stick model (Bennett, 1996, 2005). Rarefaction analysis (Birks and Line, 1992) was applied to provide an estimate of the palynological richness in each sample.

Detrended Correspondence Analysis (DCA), an unconstrained ordination method (Hill and Gauch, 1980) detects trends in community or taxa composition over time. Constrained ordination, Canonical Correspondence Analysis (CCA) identifies the environmental variable whose dynamics have the highest correlation with the observed patterns of taxa composition (ter Braak, 1986). In this study, the environmental variables included are microscopic fossil charcoal, magnetic susceptibility and organic matter content. Both ordinations were computed in CANOCO 4.5 (ter Braak and Smilauer, 2002).

sec.title: Chronology
sec.p: Results from dating the sequence indicate that the sedimentary record taken from the transitional forest began accumulating ~1230 cal. yr BP with no apparent hiatus. The linear age–depth model we utilized indicates that our reconstructed ecological data have temporal resolution of ~32 years per every 4 cm for the whole period (Figure 2, Appendix 1).

caption.p: Age–depth curve for the transitional forest (Pinus-Carpinus-Quercus) based on radiocarbon (with confidence intervals) and Pb210 dates using linear interpolation

sec.title: Pollen zones
sec.p: Seventy-six taxa were recognized in the sequence from the transitional forest. Pinus dominates the arboreal component while Rubus is the predominant shrub (Figure 3). Asteraceae and Poaceae are the most dominant herbaceous families (Figure 4). Aspleniaceae and Hymenophyllaceae followed by Polypodiaceae and Adiantum dominate the epiphyte spore types (Figure 4). Zonation of the pollen data resulted in three zones as follows:

caption.p: Pollen diagram for tree and shrub pollen types in the transitional forest in west-central Mexico. Percentage of each taxa are plotted against depth; also indicated are 14C ages (cal. yr BP)
Pollen diagram for herb pollen and epiphyte spore types in the transitional forest in west-central Mexico. Percentage of each taxa are plotted against depth; also indicated are 14C ages (cal. yr BP)

sec.title: Zone Z-1 (152–124 cm, 1230–1050 cal. yr BP)
sec.p: Two peaks in Pinus abundance are evident in this zone, one at ~1230 cal. yr BP and another at ~1100 cal. yr BP. Between these two peaks there was a decline in Pinus which was coincident with two sequential peaks in Carpinus and Juglans and one peak in Salix. Quercus, although with low percentages, shows the same pattern as Pinus, while Alnus abundance was the highest for this zone; Cleyera and Melastomataceae were abundant at ~1230 cal. yr BP but were absent thereafter within this zone (Figure 3). Epiphyte spores such as Hymenophyllaceae, Polypodiaceae and Adiantum were scarce while Aspleniaceae reached high percentages in this zone (Figure 4). Most of the herbaceous taxa were absent or, if present (e.g. Asteraceae, Poaceae and Chenopodiaceae), they had very low abundances. The sum of cloud forest taxa in terms of pollen abundance of cloud forest species was nearly 50% in this zone (Figure 5).

caption.p: Sum of all taxa representative of cloud forest and sum of all herbaceous taxa (e.g. Plantago, Asteraceae, Poaceae) in the three different zones of the transitional forest in west-central Mexico. Palynological richness is also displayed by zone

sec.title: Zone Z-2 (124–44 cm, 1050–690 cal. yr BP)
sec.p: This zone has the lowest palynological richness at 1050 cal. yr BP (Figure 5). Some taxa representative of cloud forest (Juglans, Trichilia and Dendropanax) were conspicuously absent while others such as Cleyera, Tilia and Hedyosmum had low abundances (Figure 3). Consequently, the sum of all cloud forest taxa was the lowest in this zone relative to the others (Figure 5). The herbaceous component was high in this zone (Figure 5) as represented by Asteraceae, Poaceae, and Plantago (Figure 4). Zea was constrained to this zone and made its first appearance in the record at ~710 cal. yr BP. Hymenophyllaceae, Polypodiaceae and Adiantum had the maximum percentages values while Aspleniaceae had the minimum values of the three zones (Figure 4).

sec.title: Zone Z-3 (44–0 cm, 690 cal. yr BP to present)
sec.p: Taxa specific to cloud forest such as Carpinus, Dendropanax, Trichilia, Piper and Ilex increased in this zone as compared with the previous one (Figure 3). Pinus and Acacia reached their highest abundance as well. The greatest peak in palynological richness occurred at 670 cal. yr BP (Figure 5). The percentage of herbaceous taxa, mainly Asteraceae and Poaceae declined when compared with the previous zone. Zea was absent and, except for the first part of the zone, Plantago was nearly absent as well (Figure 4). Spores of Hymenophyllaceae, Polypodiaceae and Adiantum were reduced while those of Aspleniaceae increased (Figure 4).

sec.title: Unconstrained ordination
sec.p: Detrended Correspondence Analysis (DCA) revealed three groups of plant communities which correspond with the three zones (Z-1 to Z-3) previously described (Figure 6). The cluster in zone Z-3 is more aligned to zone Z-2 along axis 1 while Z-3 is more aligned to Z-1 in axis 2 (Figure 6).

caption.p: Unconstrained ordination (using DCA) of ages revealing a cyclic model. Crosses represent ages in zone Z-1 from 1230 to 1050 cal. yr BP; circles represent ages in Z-2 from 1050 to 690 cal. yr BP; squares represent ages in Z-3 from 690 cal. yr BP to present. The dotted line exemplified the path of the cyclic model starting from Z-1, passing through Z-2 and finishing at Z-3, in the same position of Z-1 in axis 1

sec.p: When ordering the taxa by zone the following results emerged: Zone Z-1, which encompasses 1230 to 1050 cal. yr BP, contained cloud forest arboreal taxa that were differentiated into three different clusters. One cluster is located in the upper right hand corner (Piper, Hedyosmum, Tilia, Ilex and Fraxinus), another is in the middle-left section (Carpinus and Juglans) and another is in the center (Clethra and Magnolia). Quercus, Pinus and Alnus are distant from the clusters and dispersed along axis 2, while herbaceous taxa such as Asteraceae, Poaceae and Chenopodiaceae reveal the same pattern and Salix is an extreme point at the bottom right of the diagram as (Figure 7a).

caption.p: Unconstrained ordination (using DCA) of taxa composition by zone: (a) Z-1; (b) Z-2; (c) Z-3. Taxa names in Appendix 2

sec.p: In zone Z-2, which includes the period 1050 to 690 cal. yr BP, most of the cloud forest arboreal taxa, excepting Tilia, are arranged at the right side of axis 1. Pinus, Quercus and Alnus, together with Asteraceae, Poaceae, Chenopodiaceae and Zea are in the left of axis 1. As in zone 1, Salix is again separated from any cluster (Figure 7b).

In zone Z-3 (ages from 690 cal. yr BP to present) the cloud forest arboreal taxa are dispersed in the whole diagram. Pinus, Quercus and Alnus are in the center of the diagram closer to Salix and to the herbaceous taxa Chenopodiaceae and Poaceae (Figure 7c).

sec.title: The environment
sec.p: Magnetic susceptibility increased at ~1020 cal. yr BP, decreased at 720 cal. yr BP then showed an abrupt rise at ~400 cal. yr BP. Microscopic fossil charcoal dynamics were discontinuous through the sequence but displayed a maximum value at ~560 cal. yr BP. Organic matter values were generally continuous, yet they showed a substantial peak at 720 cal. yr BP (Figure 8).

caption.p: Changes in environmental variables represented by microscopic fossil (CHAR) charcoal, magnetic susceptibility (MS) and organic matter content (OMC) for the transitional forest in west-central Mexico

sec.title: Constrained ordination
sec.p: Canonical Correspondence Analysis revealed one large cluster and three small clusters with respect to the direction of change in the three vectors associated with the environmental variables (i.e. organic matter, magnetic susceptibility and microcharcoal) (Figure 9). Magnetic susceptibility was the main explanatory variable for taxa composition in axis 1, which explained 13.1% of the variance in this variable, while organic matter was predominant in axis 2 that explained 17.9% of its total variance.

caption.p: Constrained ordination (using CCA) of taxa composition and environmental variables. Taxa names in Appendix 2

sec.p: In axis 1, those taxa closely associated with microscopic fossil charcoal such as Cornus, Arisaema, Leguminosae, Solanaceae and Juncaceae were present at ~910 cal. yr BP when a peak in microscopic fossil charcoal arose (Figures 8 and 9). Sebastiana, also related to microscopic fossil charcoal, is a rare taxon present only at ~560 cal. yr BP where another microscopic fossil charcoal peak is evident.

Piper, Acacia, Prunus and Trophis were related to magnetic susceptibility. The first two occurred with their highest abundance at ~400 cal. yr BP when a peak in magnetic susceptibility was evident. Prunus and Trophis were also present around the same age (Figures 8 and 9).

In axis 2, the cluster with Lepechinia, Vaccinum and Metastelma ran closer to the organic matter vector. These are rare taxa present only at age 0 cal. yr BP when there was a peak in organic matter (Figures 8 and 9). Tilia, which is one of the taxon closer to organic matter vector as well, reached its greatest abundance at 720 cal. yr BP where the highest value in organic matter occurred.

sec.title: Successional stages in a transitional forest
sec.p: Three successional stages can be discerned along the last ~1230 years of vegetation change in the transitional forest of the Sierra de Manantlan Biosphere Reserve. These include an early cloud forest stage from 1230 to 1050 cal. yr BP (Z-1); a stage dominated by herbaceous taxa and decreased cloud forest taxa from 1050 to 690 cal. yr BP (Z-2); and finally the return of the cloud forest stage from 690 cal. yr BP to present (Z-3). This pattern of succession resembles the cyclical model as proposed by Watt in 1947 (Frelich, 2002), which begins with a transition from an initial assemblage into an intermediate stage after a disturbance event and ends with a return to the initial assemblage following recovery. The results of the unconstrained ordination with DCA show that the compositional changes over time conformed to this pattern. For example, the arrangement of Z-1 and Z-3 in the same position along axis 2 highlights their similarities in taxa composition, despite their separation in time by ~400 years. The taxa composition in Z-2 is separated from the composition of Z-1 along both axes and, although it is also separated from Z-3, the variation in taxa composition of Z-2 appears to be continuous between Z-2 to Z-3 along axis 1. These results show that every successional stage was unique in its taxa composition and its temporal dynamics. Here we discuss the successional patterns of each stage, followed by an interpretation of the drivers of succession between each stage.

sec.title: The earliest cloud forest stage
sec.p: The earliest cloud forest stage from ~1230 to 1050 cal. yr BP was characterized by the high abundance of trees such as Alnus, Carpinus, Salix and Juglans and epiphytes represented by the Aspleniaceae family. The absence of most of the herbaceous taxa (e.g. Begonia, Crotalaria, Dalea, Desmodium, Plantago, Caryophyllaceae and Solanaceae) and low abundances of others such as Asteraceae, Poaceae and Chenopodiaceae is typical of forest with closed canopies contributing for evidences of a cloud forest stage for this time. The three clusters within this zone as demarcated by DCA (Figure 7a) contain taxa representative of cloud forest and they are organized along axis 1 according to co-occurrence in time. Taxa in the same cluster were either present (e.g. Carpinus and Juglans or Clethra and Magnolia) or absent (Piper and Hedyosmum) during the same time interval, which indicates the presence of temporal heterogeneity in the canopy dominance.

Temporal variability in resource accessibility has been acknowledged as a driver that affects species diversity while changes in species composition tend to be driven by changes in climate (Brown et al., 2001). In the record presented here it would appear that climatic changes controlled the resilience of the cloud forest community, while changes in individual species’ abundances were best explained by temporal niche partitioning (Fargione and Tilman, 2005), whereby plant coexistence occurs via partitioning of taxa over time. In this study, temporal partitioning of taxa within each community appears to have been driven by changes in disturbance regimes.

sec.title: The decrease of the cloud forest
sec.p: A decrease in cloud forest taxa is observed from ~1050 to 690 cal. yr BP. The high number of herbaceous taxa, particularly Poaceae, Asteraceae and Plantago suggest an opening of the canopy (Brown and Hebda, 2003; Bush et al., 2004). The presence of Zea which is only found in this zone could be evidence that humans were responsible for vegetation changes in this stage. An endemic perennial ‘teosinte’ or ‘wild maize’, Zea diploperennis, was discovered in the SMBR more than three decades ago (Iltis et al., 1979). Some authors considered ‘teosinte’ as the ancestor of maize (Bennetzen et al., 2001), as the main contributor to the formation of maize varieties in Mexico and to its domestication through human selection (Eubanks, 2001; Hubbard et al., 2002; Iltis, 2000; Wang et al., 1999). ‘Teosinte’ has also been associated with anthropogenic disturbances in the study area (Sanchez-Velasquez et al., 2002). Even though Zea pollen classification was not possible to species level, evidence of either Zea diploperennis or Zea mays could be attributed to human activities in the transitional forest of the study area.

The herbaceous component (Rubus, Dalea, Crotalaria, Plantago, Asteraceae and Poaceae) in this stage was regularly demarcated from most of the cloud forest tree and shrub taxa in the unconstrained ordination diagram. The fern Pteridium aquilinum, which is considered to be a postdisturbance colonizer (Engelman and Nyland, 2006; Whittle et al., 1997), was grouped with the herbaceous taxa.

Aspleniaceae, a taxon associated with cloud forest in the study area (Figueroa-Rangel et al., 2008), is the only epiphyte family that decreased during this period; in contrast Polypodiaceae and Hymenophyllaceae presented high values. The Hymenophyllaceae family is known for a high tolerance to aridity (Proctor, 2003) and some Polypodiaceae plants are desiccation-resistant ferns (Andrade and Nobel, 1997; Muslin and Homann, 1992), which suggests that this period could have been drier than the previous zone.

Burning episodes were frequent during this interval in time as indicated by three peaks in microscopic fossil charcoal concentration. The peak at ~910 cal. yr BP matched a peak in Piper and the presence of infrequent taxa such as Cornus, Arisaema, Leguminosae, Juncaceae and Solanaceae. This fire event appears to have triggered a turnover in taxa composition, which allowed the establishment of taxa that are linked with fire occurrence. Fire is considered to be a mechanism for maintaining species composition (Bond and Keeley, 2005) and, according to Buhk et al. (2006), herbaceous plants are favoured by abundant light and nutrient availability following fires, a situation that increases their abundances.

sec.title: The recent cloud forest stage
sec.p: The cloud forest recovered and was present from ~690 cal. yr BP to present, with a higher palynological richness and more rare taxa (Inga, Sebastiana, Trophis and Vaccinum) as compared with the previous cloud forest stage recorded from ~1230 to 1050 cal. yr BP. Even though Piper, Carpinus, Magnolia, Hedyosmum and Dendropanax are abundant in this stage, the taxa composition was more widely dispersed in Z-3 relative to Z-1 with respect to axis 1.

A higher frequency or level of disturbance is apparent during this stage, particularly during the last ~400 years. Evidences for this are: a higher abundance of Pinus, higher peaks in microscopic fossil charcoal as compared with the two previous stages and the highest magnetic susceptibility of the last 1230 years. The highest peaks in magnetic susceptibility and microscopic fossil charcoal occurred at ~370 cal. yr BP (~ad 1570), which coincided with peak abundance of Acacia and Piper. Acacia is present in modern pine-oak and oak forests in the region and elsewhere (Greenberg and Bichier, 2005; Vazquez-Garcia et al., 1995), particularly in disturbed sites (Purata et al., 1999) and is often associated with livestock grazing (Greenberg et al., 1997). Pinus, Quercus and Alnus were grouped together in the unconstrained ordination diagram of the recent cloud forest stage, with a maximum distance of 0.5 standard deviations between them. They were clustered with the herbaceous taxa (Asteraceae and Poaceae) and Rubus, a shrub that is often associated with human disturbances. Pinus, Quercus and Alnus are also regularly associated with fire (Agee, 2000; Brown and Hebda, 2003; Carrion et al., 2000) and they characterize high-altitude ecosystems in Mexico (Rzedowskii, 1981) where human disturbances are recurrent. An archaeological study in the Autlan region revealed that the site has been occupied from ad1200 by human population practicing agriculture (Kelly, 1945); it is reasonable to think that humans have been an important disturbance factor in the transitional forest transformations; on the other hand fires are recognized as an important driver for pine expansion in some regions of Mexico (Almeida-Lenero et al., 2005; Ludlow-Wiechers et al., 2005), as well as in the Sierra de Manantlan, over the last millennia (Figueroa-Rangel et al., 2008).

sec.title: Factors triggering succession in the transitional forest
sec.p: Changes in taxa composition were primarily driven by responses of individual taxa to changes in fire occurrence and soil erosion. However, changes in the successional stages, in particular the shift from the initial cloud forest stage to a community with relatively abundant drought-resistant epiphytes appears to be related to a regional climate change event. Previous studies from a nearby pine forest detected a dry period from ad 750 to 1100 (Figueroa-Rangel et al., 2008) and from ad 710 to 1120 in the cloud forest (Figueroa-Rangel et al., 2010). In North Mexico the driest years were ad 936, 1034, 1150 and 1253 (Cook et al., 2004) amongst a period of continuous aridity between ad 900 and 1300. A similar arid interval has been reported for Central Mexico around ~ad 1000 (Arnauld et al., 1997; Metcalfe, 1995; Metcalfe and Hales, 1994) and for the Yucatan Peninsula from ~ad 800 to 1000 (Hodell et al., 1995, 2001, 2005).

It is possible that during the drier period, water was limited in the lowlands, which may have driven people to undertake agriculture in the more humid highlands. In Kelly’s (1945) archaeological work in the Autlan-Tuxcacuesco zone, there is also a recurrent allusion to the insufficient water supply in the Autlan valley and the frequent demise of maize crops over the years. So even in wet years, water was an important issue for people in the valley. The presence of Zea in Z-2, where the dry period is believed to occur, supports our supposition that human disturbances in the transitional forest increased between 1050 and 690 cal. yr BP

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The present transitional forest dominated by Pinus-Quercus-Carpinus in west-central Mexico has developed by way of three different successional stages during the last ~1230 years. Successional trajectories resembled a cyclic model whereby the initial stage of cloud forest shifted to an intermediate stage dominated by herbaceous taxa after ~110 years. This was coincident with forest contraction that lasted for ~400 years (1050 to 690 cal. yr BP) following a climate change event ~ad 800 to 1200 that was evident across several regions of Mexico; finally the cloud forest recovered during the last ~680 years.

Environmental changes such as an increase in forest fires and soil erosion drove turnover in taxa composition within each successional stage. Thus, changes in the abundance of individual taxa occurred in response to disturbances. However, these disturbances were not found to cause a shift from a cloud forest community to transitional forest. Temporal heterogeneity in the abundance of individual taxa may have played an important role in cloud forest resilience following a disturbance, where some taxa disappeared for hundreds years and then reappeared when environmental conditions allowed them to do so.

The recent cloud forest assemblage (i.e. the last ~680 years) is dominated by human-induced taxa such as Pinus, Acacia, Rubus and Parathesis. Fire occurrences and soil erosion have also increased during the last ~400 years. This suggests a link between the unique taxa of the recent cloud forest and human activities. We have shown that cloud forest resilience is highly dependent on the predominant climate. Therefore, given expected future climate changes, any increase in human-induced disturbances could shift the cloud forest to a pine- or pine–oak-dominated forest. These results support the conservation strategies currently in place in the study area, including the exclusion of agriculture, livestock grazing and timber harvesting for the preservation of the cloud forest community in the Sierra de Manantlan Biosphere Reserve.

caption.p: Radiocarbon calibrated dates calculated from CALIB v5.02 and INTCAL04.14 programs (Reimer et al., 2004) used to develop the chronology for the transitional forest in west-central, Mexico
Abbreviations for taxa considered in the study
